title: Inlined recursive type error can be dodged, leading to compiler overflowing its stack

labels.name: I-ICE
labels.description: Issue: The compiler panicked, giving an Internal Compilation Error (ICE) ❄️

labels.name: E-needs-test
labels.description: Call for participation: writing correctness tests

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
```Rust
// If the inner `Foo` is named through an associated type, the "infinite size" error does not occur.
struct Foo(<&'static Foo as ::core::ops::Deref>::Target);
// But Rust will be unable to know whether `Foo` is sized or not,
// and it will infinitely recurse somewhere trying to figure out the size of this pointer (is my guess):
const _: *const Foo = 0 as _;
```

This happens on `1.0.0`, `stable`, and `nightly` (haven't checked the others).

### Error

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9920355/177039840-804a3864-6b0c-44c2-b3ed-0001a82e89c7.png)

On older toolchains, it succintly says:

> thread `rustc` has overflowed its stack

On newer ones, it yields:
